user.biography: Writer. Creator. Instigator. Not your dad.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on July 25, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person.

node.text:
This is Robert Smalls — businessman, politician, publisher, and pirate — in other words, you could say Mr. Smalls had it all. But, none of this would have been true if he hadn’t risked everything back in May of 1862. Born into slavery in 1839, Robert was favored by his “owner” (typing that about a person feels so fucking gross) and, although his mother worked the house, she would have Robert regularly sent to the fields to understand the atrocities of slavery. As Robert grew older, the favor he and his mother held allowed him to take a job along the Charleston waterfront, where he could keep $1 per week of his earnings; the rest went to Master McKee (think about that the next time you complain about taxes). By his late teens, Robert knew the ins and outs of Charleston better than most men. In 1856, with both owners’ permission, he married Hannah Jones. The couple had two children and Robert attempted to purchase Hannah’s freedom, but the price was set to be intentionally unattainable. In 1861, the Civil War had begun; Robert was assigned to work on the CSS Planter. After a year of learning the ship’s procedures, Robert helped his family and others sneak aboard while the officers were absent (probably in a brothel or some shit). Then, in the early morning hours of May 13, 1862, embracing the “I’m the captain now” mentality at the age of 23, Robert donned the captain’s hat and set sail with a plan to burn the ship — and go down with it — if capture seemed imminent. Using the correct signals, he was able to escape the harbor. And, by the time the guards realized what happened, Robert had already raised a white flag and was sailing directly into the Union fleet. Due to his heroic actions, he was given his freedom, a legitimate captain position, and prize money for capturing a Confederate vessel. Smalls went on to invest in several businesses, serve five terms in congress, and dedicate his life to reform. In 1915, he died in the SAME DAMN HOUSE he was born in as a slave 75 years prior. (Robert purchased the property in a tax sale after the war ended — now THAT’S what you call a flex move.)

Well, you just learned some fucking history. You’re welcome. #SUNDAYSCHOOL

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Captain @sgrstk People will suggest you fix things about yourself, not because they want to help you, but because they want you to help them be more comfortable around you. Watch out for that shit then, tell whomever it is, "If you're looking for comfort, go buy a fucking blanket." 7:45 PM 26 Jun 19'.

node.text: "Put that blanket over your head, pretend you're a ghost, and float the fuck away from me."

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on July 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Captain @sgrstk In life, you'll be misunderstood. At some point, you'll be made out to be something you're not. When this happens, it's not as important to defend yourself as it is to know yourself. Know who you are, know what you mean, and know enough to feel secure even though you're not seen. 6:54 PM 09 Jul 21'.

node.text: Know yourself and nobody will be able to convince you that you're something else.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on July 07, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person and indoor.

node.text:
Instagram, meet Ethan Finch.

“Ethan, there’s no need to meet Instagram or the rest of social media for quite a while. In a world of algorithms meant to make you feel irrelevant, spend time around people who fill your world with confidence. Discover what you like about life without the brassy voice of public opinion ranking your every decision. Make memories for you; not for others to peruse. Sneak out at night and experience life in a new light. Get your hands dirty, but keep your conscious clean. Don’t allow trends to determine your friends. Do things without overthinking the outcome. Learn to think and speak for yourself while allowing others to do the same. Know that good things will come and go, but with every loss comes an opportunity to grow. Always remember that doing what’s right for you is more important than what others think of you. Take risks, but don’t be afraid to ask for help (especially from dad). Have a firm handshake, but a flexible forgiveness policy. Be yourself before anyone else. Give your dreams your attention; they’ll die if you neglect them. Assume all strangers are having a bad day and let your initial interaction with them be something to make it better. Make mistakes, then make the most of those mistakes by choosing to learn from them instead of run from them. Believe in yourself, but don’t believe you know everything. Don’t make a habit of lying because nobody makes a habit of hanging out with liars. Be humble, but at the same time, don't be afraid to humble someone. Create your own path whenever existing paths leave you lost. Be reliable; it’s the easiest way to be likeable. Speak your truth, even when you know it will change the way somebody thinks of you. Trust your gut and your dog; both are a great judge of character. Don’t make a permanent decision due to an embarrassing situation. Always try something new even if it means you’ll look like a fool. Never let your ego prevent you from letting go. Bury the hatchet, but never bury your head. Have a routine as well as a willingness to rethink things. Don’t let a quest for popularity change the best parts of your personality. Lastly, be patient with yourself — life takes time."

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on June 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Captain @sgrstk Be humble, but at the same the time, don't be afraid to humble someone. In other words, know your worth without having to show but feel free to flex on anyone who tries to devalue it. 6:38 PM 22 Jun 21 View Tweet activity'.

node.text: “Would you rather be feared or loved?” I remember being asked this question back in 2016 and, without hesitation, I responded, “Feared, obviously.” (By the way, you can thank Niccolò Machiavelli, not Michael Scott, for that ego-probing thought.) Now, it’s tempting to go with “feared” because people often hurt the ones they love — but they will rarely even risk hurting someone they fear — right? True. The people you love, and the people who love you, will hurt you (and vice versa). That’s just life. Shit happens, communication sucks, and mistakes are made. Does it hurt? Fuck yeah it does. But, does it mean that being loved is the lesser of the two options? Nope. Anyone who needs or desires to be feared constantly is making that choice because of their own fear and insecurity. They want to be feared because they’re either (a) afraid you’ll see them for who they truly are or (b) afraid of being hurt themselves. In other words, they want to control the unavoidable. Consequently, the desire to be feared comes with A LOT of stress, self-doubt, and straight-up paranoia (just look back on all the iron-fisted political leaders throughout history who literally lost their goddamn minds due to their own insecurities). Anyway, my point to this post is simple: Being loved is far superior to being feared — and being humble will absolutely make your life easier — however, there will be times when you can’t let somebody get off too easily. There’s a difference between seeking fear and requiring respect. Life is a matter of balance, and sometimes, maintaining that balance means somebody’s bullshit needs to be silenced.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on June 20, 2021. May be an image of ‎book, outdoors, tree and ‎text that says '‎سن F*CKING HISTORY‎'‎‎.

node.text: Just a heads-up, if you fucked up and forgot about dad today, I just left some signed copies of my book "Fucking History" in the Little Free Library box located at 2064 Surrey Lane in Las Vegas. Oh, and unless you legitimately have multiple people in your life who you consider to be your father, do the other dads out there a favor and please only take one copy. Happy Father's Day. (I'm about to become a dad myself any day now — just waiting for him to come out.)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on June 08, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: The early morning light in this corner of my living room kind of feels like a scene from "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom." And, I like that.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on June 06, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'The Captain @sgrstk I really wanted to have my shit have together before my son was born. And, in trying to do that, realized that a lot of "my shit" wasn't mine to begin with was carrying shit for other people out of habit or a desire to maintain a reputation. Chances are, you're doing it now. 8:46 PM 06 May 21'.

node.text: In preparation for packing around a miniature human, I’ve been unpacking and examining much of the shit that I’ve gathered during my 34 years on this planet . . . All the fears, the anxieties, and the stressors in my life that culminate into behaviors that I don’t want my son to inherit. I have no desire to raise a clone of myself. Rather, I hope to set my son up to be the best version of himself — and, for all I know — his best version is absolutely nothing like me (honestly, that would be great because the last thing this world needs is another “Kyle”). Now, over the past few months, I’ve had days of feeling inadequate, days of feeling more than capable, and days of feeling like, well, absolute fucking hell. But, even on the worst days — the days that had me thinking, “What the fuck is wrong with me and why does this or that still bother me?” — I’ve been able to learn something about myself, which is why I’m writing this caption today . . . In life, many of us carry more than is necessary. Meaning, we carry not only our own emotions and problems, but also the emotions and problems of those around us. And, in doing so, we take responsibility for how others are feeling — when, in reality — it’s not even our hand to be playing. Here’s what I mean by that: When life deals somebody a hand (desirable or not), it isn’t our responsibility to ensure that they play their cards correctly. Throughout much of my adulthood, I’ve felt the need to be a provider for my friends, my family, and even complete strangers (a part of my nature that will probably never change). However, when left unrestricted, this mindset can add much more emotional weight than you ever anticipated. So, I’ve stopped feeling the frustration of watching friends make dumb decisions, I’ve stopped feeling responsible for rescuing a family member from self-inflicted complications, and I’ve seen the hypocrisy of having the phrase “not your dad” in my bio for years while simultaneously allowing so many people in my life to treat me like their dad. But, as I ready myself to be a real dad, I’ve realized the importance of not just allowing, but actually requiring, others to play their own hand — good or bad.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on June 05, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'The Captain @sgrstk The fact that some people go to a restaurant and treat the staff like shit is fucking ridiculous. You CHOSE to go out to eat. If you feel the need to be rude while you're waiting for your Ûooo stay the fuck home and yell at your microwave. 1:39 PM 29 Apr Apr19'.

node.text:
If you go out to eat this weekend, remember, your server is a person.

P.S. Jim Carrey never said this, so don't even come at me with that bullshit. Don't get me wrong, Jim Carrey is wise as hell and I love his outlook on society as a whole. However, I wrote this and — shortly after it became popular — a large meme account put his face on it so they wouldn't have to credit me (because using a celebrity will make it seem like they aren't stealing content; thus, Instagram won't do anything about it). Unfortunately, this is what happens to many writers and creators today. In fact, a lot of the jokes that you hear on late-night TV are actually taken from original tweets that were trending just a few weeks earlier.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Kyle Creek, aka "The Captain" on May 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Tweet The Captain @sgrstk Don't ask her to hang; ask her on a date. Hanging is fucking weak. It's for teenagers, bats, and guys who wear sandals in non-sand settings. 5:35 PM 26 May 17 山 View Tweet activity'.

node.text: To make this even easier to remember, #TBT means this advice is old, but it also stands for: Teenage Bat Toes.
